passage: While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes: • Tennessee Williams was an American playwright known for his poetic style. • His play 'A Streetcar Named Desire' premiered in 1947, starring Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy. • Williams received the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for 'A Streetcar Named Desire.' • Blanche DuBois, one of the play's central characters, represents the fading Old South.
question: Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to describe the significance of 'A Streetcar Named Desire'?

choices.A: Tennessee Williams, an American playwright, wrote 'A Streetcar Named Desire' in 1947.
choices.B: Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy starred in the premiere of 'A Streetcar Named Desire,' a play by Tennessee Williams.
choices.C: 'A Streetcar Named Desire,' a Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Tennessee Williams, explores the fading Old South through the character of Blanche DuBois.
choices.D: Blanche DuBois, a character in 'A Streetcar Named Desire,' represents the Old South, a recurring theme in Tennessee Williams' works.

explanation: C: 'A Streetcar Named Desire,' a Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Tennessee Williams, explores the fading Old South through the character of Blanche DuBois. This answer effectively describes the significance of the play by mentioning its Pulitzer Prize and the exploration of the Old South.
distractor_explanation: 'Tennessee Williams, an American playwright, wrote 'A Streetcar Named Desire' in 1947.' is incorrect because it only provides basic information about the playwright and the year the play was written, without delving into the significance of the play.

'Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy starred in the premiere of 'A Streetcar Named Desire,' a play by Tennessee Williams.' is incorrect because it focuses on the actors in the premiere rather than the significance of the play itself.

'Blanche DuBois, a character in 'A Streetcar Named Desire,' represents the Old South, a recurring theme in Tennessee Williams' works.' is incorrect because it focuses on the character Blanche DuBois and the recurring theme in Williams' works, but does not mention the play's Pulitzer Prize or its overall significance.
